 There's a couple of problems. The largest wooden ships were just over 300 ft in length. There were 9 six masted schooners built between 1900 and 1909. They leaked from the day they hit the water because even a gentle swell caused hogging and snaking that sprung the hull timbers beyond any known method of calking - most certainly beyond a simple slathering with pitch. There was also another ship of comparable length, the four-masted medium clipper barque, Great Republic built in 1853. The latter had 90 steel cross braces, 4 inches wide, 1 inch thick and 336 feet long. She still leaked. Most of these ships were lost in storms, even while anchored in the lee of an island.
 
 But that isn't even the full extent of the bad news. Any experienced sailor will tell you how important it is that a ship maintain headway during a storm in order to keep the attitude of the ship oriented to the waves correctly. Sailing ships had to fly at least some sail so that they could keep the stern to the wave front. Modern ships put bow into the waves. The reasons are simple. A ship without power (or a big box like an ark) would get turned broadside to the waves, a disaster in heavy seas. If the height of the wave front is greater than the dimension of the ship, then as the wave begins to pass and the ship is carried up the wave, before it reaches the top it will slide down the face into the trough where the gunwale will be driven under. As the wave passes, it will roll the ship. In 1944 four ships of the U.S. Navy lost power during a typhoon in the Pacific and capcized when the waves turned them with their beams to the waves.

The fact that ancient societies conferred maleness upon their gods seems to me to be nothing more than a reflection of cultural bias. For example, the Hebrews were a patriarchal society, so it made perfect sense for them to attribute maleness to their god. Some societies viewed the earth as being female, in consort with a male sky-god. Rain was thus considered to be the semen of the sky-god, which caused plants to pop out of the ground. 
 
 Likewise, the god of the Hebrews lived somewhere in the sky above the earth. You find references to this throughout the entire Judeo/Christian Bible. Genesis 11 tells us that God looked down and came down in order to check out the tower of Babel. Jesus is reported to have ascended into the sky, bodily, toward heaven. This assumes that heaven exists as some physical location in the sky. Likewise, Paul tells us that Jesus would soon return to earth from the sky, through the clouds, to gather up the faithful and to bring them back to heaven with him.

But Jim,
 
 If this great flood killed everyone in the world but 8 people on a little ark, and if we find their story in the Bible, who invented all of these other flood stories. Isn't it more reasonable that since so few tell the same story as the Bible, that they recount different flood mythology? Isn't it reasonable that since mankind has always had a proclivity for settling on floodplains the the vast majority of these myths relate to local floods.
 
 However, there is no evidence in the geology of the earth that there ever was a universal flood. There isn't enough water on earth to raise water levels high enough to cover even low mountain ranges, much less flood to a depth greater than Everest. But the "something" to the story is that many primative people suffered floods and incorporated stories about them into their oral traditions and mythology.
 
It's also amazing how so many of you think science and laws of nature should preclude miracles. I call that lack of faith.

 Exactly. If we can explain the things that happen in the world around us by naturalistic means, why should we throw are hands up into the air and give up and declare a miracle? Faith means to believe without evidence.
 
Don't try to tell me nothing like that ever happened.

 Nobody is telling you that there have never been floods. But there is no evidence of a universal flood. Looking at the geology of the earth, fossil lakes and rivers, and even deserts are quite apparent. Any geologist recognizes them when he sees them in the strata. And floods are also quite apparent. But there is not layer that is found everywhere around the globe that could possible correspond to a universal flood.

Check out the linked site. Check out the links within that site. Stories of floods and great floods have come from all over the world. Don't try to tell me nothing like that ever happened.

 
 I could tell you a couple of pretty good flood stories myself, and the biggest river I've lived near is basically a creek.
 
 Floods are common throughout geological history, and some would no doubt seem like they flooded the world, if you're world consisted of everything within a few days walking distance. Combine that with the fact that human settlement is generally located along waterways or coastlines, and it's not hard to see how flooding could easily become a part of mythology for most cultures around the world. It's a powerful force of nature, yet relatively common.
 
 To suggest that every story is talking about the same flood at the same time is rather absurd IMHO.

Jim:
 
 
Flood myths are widespread, but they are not all the same myth. They differ in many important aspects, including 
 reasons for the flood. (Most do not give a reason.) 
 who survived. (Almost none have only a family of eight surviving.) 
 what they took with them. (Very few saved samples of all life.) 
 how they survived. (In about half the myths, people escaped to high ground; some flood myths have no survivors.) 
 what they did afterwards. (Few feature any kind of sacrifice after the flood.) 
 The biblical flood myth has close parallels only to other myths from the same region, with which it probably shares a common source, and to versions spread to other cultures by missionaries (Isaak 2002). 
 
 
 Flood myths oare likely common because floods are common; the commonness of the myth in no way implies a global flood. Myths about snakes are even more common than myths about floods, but that does not mean there was once one snake surrounding the entire earth.

Obviously you don't understand what Dues Ex Machina is.

 
 1. In Greek and Roman drama, a god lowered by stage machinery to resolve a plot or extricate the protagonist from a difficult situation. 
 2. An unexpected, artificial, or improbable character, device, or event introduced suddenly in a work of fiction or drama to resolve a situation or untangle a plot. 
 3. A person or event that provides a sudden and unexpected solution to a difficulty.

But Jim,
 
 If this great flood killed everyone in the world but 8 people on a little ark, and if we find their story in the Bible, who invented all of these other flood stories. Isn't it more reasonable that since so few tell the same story as the Bible, that they recount different flood mythology? Isn't it reasonable that since mankind has always had a proclivity for settling on floodplains the the vast majority of these myths relate to local floods.
 
 However, there is no evidence in the geology of the earth that there ever was a universal flood. There isn't enough water on earth to raise water levels high enough to cover even low mountain ranges, much less flood to a depth greater than Everest. But the "something" to the story is that many primative people suffered floods and incorporated stories about them into their oral traditions and mythology.
 
 Exactly. If we can explain the things that happen in the world around us by naturalistic means, why should we throw are hands up into the air and give up and declare a miracle? Faith means to believe without evidence.
 
 Nobody is telling you that there have never been floods. But there is no evidence of a universal flood. Looking at the geology of the earth, fossil lakes and rivers, and even deserts are quite apparent. Any geologist recognizes them when he sees them in the strata. And floods are also quite apparent. But there is not layer that is found everywhere around the globe that could possible correspond to a universal flood.
Unless I slipped up somewhere, I don't believe I claimed a single universal flooding of the earth happened. It wasn't until several hundred years AD that we knew the earth was a ball. Local or regional flooding may have been recounted as global flooding because the writers knew nothing of the rest of the world.
 
 Who knows...maybe a monstrous asteroid passed between the earth and the sun, causing the darkness and pulling the oceans waters to one side of the earth...maybe Noah's area was facing the sun and the sea waters rose (in response to gravity) while it was raining, causing the earth to be covered with water on one side.
 
 Since water is such a powerful part of life everywhere on the earth, it should be expected that some story related to a great flood would come from most all parts of the world.
